repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Instead, move this information to either `vim_diff.txt` if they're
features from vim or to news.txt if they're neovim-only. This prevent
duplication of information for users and reduces maintenance.

comment_data.body: dont think this should be changed yet. not sure about the final plan for NVIM_LISTEN_ADDRESS, it might be un-deprecated for this particular purpose (which is different than its previous dual/conflicting role)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -550,8 +550,7 @@ v:searchforward
 v:servername
 		Primary listen-address of Nvim, the first item returned by
 		|serverlist()|. Usually this is the named pipe created by Nvim
-		at |startup| or given by |--listen| (or the deprecated
-		|$NVIM_LISTEN_ADDRESS| env var).
+		at |startup| or given by |--listen|.

comment_regular_data.body: Shouldn't we deprecate the deprecation of `deprecated.txt` first?
That feels unnecessary. The documentation isn't bound by any contract and I don't like setting a precedent for adding processes for documentation changes. Are you certain about this?
I'm not even serious about this. (I just like saying the word.)
I don't think this is a good idea. Scattering deprecated things across multiple files makes them difficult to find, and not every deprecation can have a straightforward tag.
I think your premise kinda breaks down in reality as people frequently forget or skip updating `deprecated.txt`, so it's not really as useful of an index as you'd think.
Unsure how to proceed. We can close if people dislike this. @neovim/core @neovim/padawans any ideas?

> I don't think this is a good idea. Scattering deprecated things across multiple files makes them difficult to find, and not every deprecation can have a straightforward tag.

I second this. In the past I found it useful to have a help tag of some deprecated functionality lead to a concise description of what I should be looking for instead. Both 'news.txt' and 'vim_diff.txt' don't feel as good places for this type of info (concise rerouting, that is).

> Both 'news.txt' and 'vim_diff.txt' don't feel as good places for this type of info (concise rerouting, that is).

Why not? I think it makes more sense since any given upgrade path for a user is gathered in one place (vim -> nvim, nvim-0.9 -> nvim-0.10...). The alternative is that this information is scattered, which is the case today.

Not only that, but since all deprecations are gathered in one massive file without any time differentiation I'd argue finding deprecations becomes *harder*, not easier. This is akin to merging all documentation files into a single `doc.txt` and then pronouncing the information is easier to find since it's all gathered in one place.

`nvim_get_api_info` has a `deprecated_since` attribute - perhaps it would make sense to auto-generate deprecated.txt from that? This would take care of the concern of people forgetting to mention deprecations in this file.
This might require enhancing `nvim_get_api_info` to also contain the name of the function replacing the deprecated item (which would be a nice improvement IMO) if there is one.

Then people who deprecate things would only need to to mention them in news.txt, and there would be an automatically generated index for developers/people looking for a replacement.

> Not only that, but since all deprecations are gathered in one massive file without any time differentiation I'd argue finding deprecations becomes _harder_, not easier. This is akin to merging all documentation files into a single `doc.txt` and then pronouncing the information is easier to find since it's all gathered in one place.

My use case is mostly this:
- I see some function in code about which I want to read help page.
- I fuzzy search help tags until I find it.
- I see it leads to 'deprecated.txt' and *right next to the target function* is its alternative. So there is no need to spend extra seconds on reading the context of news or 'vim_diff' entry. The fact that I ended up in 'news.txt' doesn't immediately mean that this function was deprecated. Although this is debatable if `*tag*` notation has lead me there, but still for me it will not be immediately obvious.

Having information about version since when it is deprecated is indeed useful. I'd indeed prefer to have this immediately accessible instead of having to search help tags in previous release appimages.

> `nvim_get_api_info` has a `deprecated_since` attribute - perhaps it would make sense to auto-generate deprecated.txt from that?

Hmm, I don't know the specifics about `nvim_get_api_info`. However, I like the idea of generating `deprecated.txt` if it's feasible.

generating deprecated.txt would be very good. 

but until then, to avoid the duplication, maybe we should move the "news" deprecations into deprecated.txt, then the news.txt files only link-to deprecated.txt. And deprecated.txt could have different sections for each Nvim version.

title: docs: remove deprecated.txt
